page.lettertext:
fol.152r
Belgia 1594 13 July To S
r
Ro: Cecill
May it please yo
r
H. to be advertised,
at
e inclosed
to her
Ma
tie
was brought me this morning by
e Greffier
of
e
states:
and is an answear to
at letter, w
ch
her
Ma
tie
writte unto them, and was sent hither by yo
r
H.
to be delivered by me. It concerned
e abuse of their
trafficque into
Spaine,
in transporting suche materials
as served
e
King
for
e furnishing of his navies. Wherein
they doe endevo
r
to satisfie her Ma
tie
and they signifie
their forwardnesse to assist her purpose in subduing
e
Spaniardes in
Britaine.
The copie of
e Letter I send
yo
r
H. heerew
t
, having no other mater to certifie beside,
but
at w
ch
I writte but two daies past unto my L:
Treasurer: wherof I doe account
at yo
r
H. is partaker.
Onely this is written since,
at
Co. Maurice
and
e towne
upon l
re
s and messengers sent too and fro, have resol-
v ed in a maner (for it is not yet concluded) that
those of
Groeninghen
shall sette downe in writing upon
w
at
conditions they will yelde, and then after from
e
Count they shall knowe to w
at
pointes the states will
condescend. So
at nowe it doth appeare by all their
proceeding,
at they w
t
in doe conceave, w
at
danger they
incurre by delaieng
e treatie, and therfor will not
differ
as all men are persuaded, to capitulat w
t
us, and
also to accept any tolerable conditions. The sooner in
as muche as
e Count doth goe forward w
t
his gal-
leries and mines, and omitteth no hostilitie.
Heere is certaine intelligence given to
e states,
at
e Enemie doth assemble about
Maestricht,
and useth
all expedition for
e rescue of Groeninghen. But
by every mans conjecture, before they can be where
they would be,
e towne will be o
rs
by force or by
faire meanes.
Wherew
t
I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. July 13 1594.
Yo
r
H. at commaundem
t
Tho. Bodley
